page.title: Connectivity
page.body:
• Stay Connected
  • How USAi Provides Redundancy Better
  • Get a Quote

Stay Connected

For most businesses it is now mission critical to stay connected to the internet 24 / 7. Without connectivity your company disappears from the Internet. Without connectivity your employees can't get work done, and your customers can't find you. Without connectivity your file servers, web servers, mail servers, and VPN remote access for employees all disappear from the Internet. Without connectivity for technology like Voice over IP (VoIP) even your phone system is unavailable when your Internet connection goes down. Never before has it been so important to stay connected!

In an effort to stay connected many companies use "multihoming" which means connecting to multiple Internet Service Providers (ISP) in the hopes that one will be up. This can often be too costly for companies or technically impractical. From a cost perspective, in order to have multiple T1 lines you will have to double your connection costs as well as purchase a router that is able to handle two Internet connections. From a technical perspective, a business would have to have its own IP space from ARIN and Autonomous System Number (ASN) to make Border Gateway Protocol (BGP) possible. Even then, smaller IP blocks are not guaranteed to be visible across the Internet. There are "black boxes" that will attempt to juggle multiple connections for you if you don't mind spending several thousand dollars...

Another consideration is the delivery media: Even if your company buys two wired connections to two different providers the chances are that both lines leave the building and go down the street on the same conduit or telephone pole so one car accident, or one construction worker who didn't call Dig Safe can still take your company to a grinding halt.

USAi.net provides redundant connectivity to the Internet: one via traditional telco based DSL, T1, T3 or Fiber Optic connection and the second via Fixed Wireless Broadband which flies right over head of any problems happening in the street. This dual path to the Internet insures that problems in the street or problems with the local telephone company and their aging copper system can't take your company down.

Back to Top

Here is how it works:

All facilities based ISPs have a data center somewhere in town and they connect to their customers via a traditional phone line like a T1. The problem is cars hit poles, construction workers dig, man hole conduits have fires. Accidents do happen that can take your business off line.

USAi.net brings connectivity, both fiber optic and wireless from our data centers up to skyscrapers and towers. We then "beam" a second connection down onto the roof of your building.

USAi.net routers make the decision to send your Internet traffic through the wire, or if the wire goes down, we reroute your Internet traffic up and over the wireless connection so that you should never be offline again. Because USAi.net is making the routing decision, no expensive router or connection juggling device is needed!

When designing your circuits we even take into consideration what telco central office your wired circuit might pass thru and try to design your second connection to come in from the other direction, further attempting to distance you from a telco related problem.

It is true you could go out and get a wired circuit from one provider, and a wireless circuit from us or one of our competitors (don't forget that expensive black box for juggling the connection) but you could spend twice as much doing that per month and also have much higher one time capital expenditure (set up fee) to get the job done. A USAi.net Dual Connection (wired with wireless combination) is guaranteed to cost less than two comparable circuits from our competition.

"If getting connected and staying connected is essential to your business, USAi.net is the ONLY one stop solution."

Back to Top

Get a Quote:

page.title: Contact Info
page.body:
There are several ways to contact USAi.net

Mailing Address
PO Box 1805
Haverhill, MA 01831

Shipping Address:
2 Washington Street
Haverhill, MA 01832

By Phone:
TOLL FREE 877-USE-USAi (877-873-7724)
Voice (978) 469-0682)
FAX (978) 373-4389

To reach our different departments:

  • Sales 877-USE-USAi ext 202
  • Support 877-USE-USAi ext 204
  • Billing 877-USE-USAi ext 205
  • Network Operations Center 877-USE-USAi ext 206

We look forward to serving you

page.title: Our History
page.body:
We started in 1997 as MVA.NET Ltd as part of an economic development initiative for the City of Haverhill in the Merrimac Valley region of Massachesetts. Being Haverhill natives we had grown tired of watching the old mill towns falling apart with age and decided to do something about it. Our region, just north of the 128 technology belt was home to Lucent and Cisco and there were many smaller high tech companies that created both software and hardware for them.

A group of us who had been successful in our professional lives decided to transform the abandoned downtown mill area into a "cyberdistrict." Some of our friends went on to be Mayor and others city councilors and still others moved their businesses into the district and we planted an ISP in the downtown area and ordered enough new telephone/data service to get the telephone company to rewire downtown Haverhill. We had about 35 businesses move into the district during the Internet boom.

By 1999 we realized that the other "business districts" namely the industrial parks at the edge of towns were located too far away from the central office to get any DSL. In addition, since business parks generally do not have residential nearby it was option impossible to get cable modems into the business parks which meant no inexpensive Internet connectivity was available out there by the highway at the edge of town.

So in 1999 we began deploying "fixed wireless broadband" to reach the parks and created a wireless cell within the park. This allowed us to create a business class Internet connection with a DSL price tag. By August of 2001 we had built tower sites throughout the lower Merrimac Valley. During 2001-2004, while many other ISPs large and small fell by the wayside, we kept on growing and even bought other ISPs.

In 2004 we purchased the assets of a nation wide wireless ISP and moved our focus onto the Boston business market. In 2005 we became the ISP for the Boston Public Library
